entry.et: Middle English weyen, from Old English wegan to move, carry, weigh way

def.dt: :to ascertain the heaviness of by or as if by a balance
:outweigh
:counterbalance
:to make heavy :weight often used with down
:to consider carefully especially by balancing opposing factors or aspects in order to reach a choice or conclusion :evaluate weighing her options
:to heave up (an anchor) preparatory to sailing
:to measure or apportion (a definite quantity) on or as if on a scales
:to have a certain heaviness :experience a specific force due to gravity
:to register a weight (as on a scales) used with in or out compare weigh in
:to merit consideration as important :count evidence will weigh heavily against him
:to press down with or as if with a heavy weight
:to have a saddening or disheartening effect guilt weighed on my mind
:to weigh anchor
:way used in the phrase under weigh
:to cause to bend down :overburden
:oppress depress
:to have oneself or one's possessions (as baggage) weighed
:to have oneself weighed in connection with an athletic contest
:to bring one's weight or influence to bear especially as a participant, contributor, or mediator weighed in with an opinion
:an act or instance of weighing in as a contestant especially in sport
:under way
